skill.name: project-scaffolder
skill.description: Creates plan.md, task.md, persona.md, project-context.md, and CLAUDE.md for new self-learning resource projects. Use when: (1) /init command is invoked, (2) setting up a new tutorial/guide/documentation project, (3) structure-designer agent needs templates for learning resource structure design. Provides hierarchical Part/Chapter/Section templates with page allocation.
skill.summary: Generates five markdown template files for organizing self-learning documentation projects with hierarchical structure and session-based task tracking.
skill.author: BitYoungjae

security_audit.summary: This skill generates documentation templates only. All static scanner detections are false positives: backticks in markdown are inline code formatting, not shell commands. The skill performs no network operations, executes no code, and creates only static markdown files with placeholder content.

low_findings.title: Markdown inline code formatting detected
low_findings.description: Scanner detected backtick syntax in markdown files. These are inline code formatting markers (e.g., `docs/path`), not Ruby/shell command execution. No command injection risk exists.

content.value_statement: Manual organization of learning resource projects leads to inconsistent structures and missed content. Project-scaffolder generates five standardized markdown templates with hierarchical organization, session-based task tracking, and placeholders for consistent documentation.
actual_capabilities: Generates five markdown template files: plan.md, task.md, persona.md, project-context.md, and CLAUDE.md
Creates hierarchical Part/Chapter/Section structure with page allocation formulas
Provides session-based task tracking with HTML comment boundaries for work sessions
Includes writer and reader persona templates with tone and code policy definitions
Adds target environment configuration and reference URL placeholders
limitations: Does not execute code or perform actual file system operations beyond template generation
Does not validate project content or check for broken links
Does not integrate with external APIs or data sources
Requires manual population of all placeholder variables after generation

use_cases.title: Tutorial Writer Setup
use_cases.description: A technical writer needs to create a multi-chapter tutorial on a programming language. The skill generates the complete project structure with parts, chapters, and sections, plus a task checklist to track progress across writing sessions.

use_cases.title: Documentation Team Onboarding
use_cases.description: A new team member needs to understand existing documentation standards. The skill provides persona.md and CLAUDE.md templates that codify writer guidelines, code policies, and terminology rules for consistent documentation.

use_cases.title: Course Creator Planning
use_cases.description: An instructor designing a self-paced learning course uses the skill to generate a structured outline with page counts, session breakdowns, and content allocation formulas to ensure comprehensive coverage.

prompt_templates.title: Initialize New Documentation Project
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the project-scaffolder skill to create a new documentation project structure for a {TOPIC} tutorial targeting {AUDIENCE}. Generate approximately {PAGE_COUNT} pages total in {LANGUAGE} language. Target environment is {ENVIRONMENT}.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new self-learning documentation project

prompt_templates.title: Add Project Structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Using project-scaffolder, create a plan.md with {NUM_PARTS} parts covering {TOPIC}. Each part should have 3-6 chapters with 3-5 sections per chapter. Allocate pages based on the standard formula.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating detailed project structure with hierarchy

prompt_templates.title: Generate Session Tasks
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a task.md file for the project. Divide the work into 3-5 session blocks with 3-5 sections each. Use HTML comments to mark session boundaries and include page estimates for each task.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating work session breakdown for progress tracking

prompt_templates.title: Define Project Standards
prompt_templates.prompt: Create persona.md and CLAUDE.md files for a project about {TOPIC}. The writer is {WRITER_PROFILE} and readers are {READER_PROFILE}. Include code policy for {LANGUAGES} and tone guidelines: {TONE_GUIDELINES}.

output_examples.input: Generate a documentation project for Python basics targeting beginners, 100 pages, in English.
output: plan.md - Contains 3 parts: Fundamentals, Data Structures, Object-Oriented Programming
task.md - 4 sessions covering introduction through advanced topics
persona.md - Writer guidelines and beginner reader profiles
project-context.md - Python environment setup and reference links
CLAUDE.md - Instructions for Claude Code AI assistant

output_examples.input: Create a project structure for a 200-page DevOps handbook with 5 parts.
output: plan.md - 5 parts: CI/CD, Containers, Cloud Infrastructure, Monitoring, Security
persona.md - DevOps writer persona with multi-language code policy
project-context.md - Docker, Kubernetes, AWS setup references
CLAUDE.md - DevOps workflow guidelines and tooling preferences

best_practices: Fill all placeholder variables like {PROJECT_TITLE}, {TARGET_AUDIENCE}, and {TOTAL_PAGES} before starting content creation
Use session boundaries in task.md to organize work into manageable 3-5 section chunks
Align chapter and section counts with the 15-30 pages per chapter guideline for balanced content
Complete persona.md before writing to ensure consistent tone and terminology throughout
anti_patterns: Skipping persona.md and CLAUDE.md results in inconsistent documentation style
Creating sections with fewer than 5 pages fragments content unnecessarily
Exceeding 6 chapters per part makes navigation difficult for readers
Starting without a complete plan.md leads to scope creep and incomplete coverage

faq.question: What is the difference between plan.md and task.md?
faq.answer: plan.md defines the complete project structure with parts, chapters, and sections. task.md mirrors this structure but adds checkboxes and session boundaries for tracking actual writing progress.

faq.question: How do I customize the templates for my project?
faq.answer: Replace all {PLACEHOLDER} variables with your specific content. The SKILL.md file lists all variables and their purposes. You can also edit the templates directly after generation.

faq.question: Can I add custom sections to the templates?
faq.answer: Yes. The templates are plain markdown files. Add, remove, or modify sections as needed. The skill provides a starting point, not a rigid structure.

faq.question: How many pages should each section contain?
faq.answer: Each section should contain 5-12 pages. Chapters contain 3-5 sections (15-30 pages total). Parts contain 3-6 chapters (50-100 pages total).

faq.question: What tools does the skill use?
faq.answer: The skill uses Read, Write, Bash, and Glob tools to generate template files. It does not execute arbitrary code or make network requests.

faq.question: How do session boundaries work in task.md?
faq.answer: Session boundaries are HTML comments like `<!-- Session 1: Part 1 -->` that mark logical work units. Each session should contain 3-5 sections or 20-40 pages of content.
